title: Thursday, 18th February, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE

So, we meet again.

BE

Those two lines of text have taken ten refreshes to deliver to your screens, which doesn't fill me with confidence for the remaining 59 minutes.

BE

Still, we'll persist. As we always do.

11:06 am
BE

Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily whatever. You know. This thing.

BE

FTSE down a bit because it went up a lot.

BE

Off 0.4% at pixel, 21 points. Which after a 9%, four day bounce, isn't exactly dramatic.

11:07 am
BE

The FTSE 100 penny stocks continue to trade as penny stocks.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 439.75, down 28.3 (-6.05%), High: 468.70, Low: 434.30, Volume: 7.72m
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 119.20, down 0.8 (-0.67%), High: 121.75, Low: 114.10, Volume: 33.60m
11:08 am
Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 1,878, down 73.5 (-3.77%), High: 1,940, Low: 1,869, Volume: 2.57m
Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 469.10, down 9.3 (-1.94%), High: 482.30, Low: 463.40, Volume: 1.05m
BE

(And before anyone shouts at me, I don't have a list of today's ex divs. Any or none of the stocks I mention might be ex, but I've not checked. Sorry.)

11:10 am
BE

The day's interest, though, is retail. So let's head straight over there.

undefined
BE

So.

11:11 am
BE

Supermarket shares gave dealers plenty of food for thought.

As J Sainsbury jumped 11.9p to 261.5p, after broker Exane BNP Paribas upgraded to outperform with a target price of 280p on further consideration of its £1.3billion bid for Home Retail’s Argos, rumours were rife that Wm Morrison’s days of independence could be numbered.

Its shares, which have ignored the surrounding market malaise and risen from 153p over the past month to close yesterday 3.3p better at 181.5p, reflected red-hot gossip that rival Tesco (6.3p dearer at 186.85p) and a private equity consortium, led by Permira, are both stalking the Bradford-based group and an offer in the region of £6.42billion, or 275p a share, could not be far away.

BE

Daily Mail, of course.

BE

http://www.dailyma...-market-share.html

11:13 am
BE

And I don't think I'll offend anyone by saying it's a bit of a flier.

BE

Sure -- there's a lot of talk at the moment about supermarket consolidation.

BE

And the combined market share of Aldi and Lidl meaning the regulator might allow four into three.

11:14 am
BE

Andrea Felsted over at Bloomberg wrote a good summary of the logic last month.

BE

http://www.bloombe...-morrison-struggle

BE

But Tesco?! And Permira?!?

11:15 am
BE

Can I digress for a second? Here's what makes fliers slightly irritating.

BE

Somewhere near the start of a bid procedure, the advisers to the predator will take a big file of press clippings to the Takeover Panel.

BE

Basically, this file will be packed full of untrue and mostly untrue rumours.

11:17 am
BE

The advisers will say, "look at all this nonsense! It would be disruptive to the process if something similar appeared over the next few months and we were forced into making a statement."

BE

And, it seems, the Panel tends to be minded to agree.

BE

Which makes it a lot harder to force out a story unless you have all the information.

11:19 am
BE

It makes any RAW below bandit1 worthless. RAW becomes binary. And there really ain't much bandit1 -grade RAW around.

BE

(@Mo06: what do you suggest we talk about?)

BE

So, for example, we know CVC and Carlyle began working with the Morrison family on a take-private back in 2014 about a takeout

11:21 am
BE

Then went pens down after Bloomberg reported it.

BE

But there was never a statement.

BE

Anyway, I could rant for some considerable time about the mysterious ways of the Takeover Panel and our constant game of shadow boxing against their vagiaries, but instead here's some sellside.

11:22 am
BE

Here's Exane to say, "Tesco!?! Permira?!?!"

BE

The Daily Mail reports that Morrison could be bid for by Tesco or PE consortium led by Permira at 275p / share. It's a heavily fallen share and the business is showing nascent signs of improvement, but a bid from Tesco looks unlikely and a 275p bid price looks far too much of a stretch for private equity, even though likely welcomed by management.

BE

The article suggests Tesco has been given legal opinion that a bid for Morrison could be cleared by the regulator. We concur that the competitive landscape has changed with the rise of the Germanic discounters and fragmentation of shopping trips but think that it would still be challenging for the 28% share market leader to acquire Morrison (11% share) in its entirety. Further, whilst consolidation in some form is required, less rather than more supermarket space ultimately is required.

As to a bid from PE, that can't be ruled out, and a period in private ownership would arguably be welcome for Morrison and its management as the business and industry goes through a period of transition.

11:24 am
BE

The question is price and viable exit options.

Morrison owns near 90% of its store estate butalternative use values remain lower - see our note, Four's a crowd, below. As such, valuation should be predominantly driven by operating cash generation, in the near-term at least. The issue is that the mooted 275p bid price implies 28x FY17E P/E, 21x EV/EBIT, greater than 0.5x EV/sales and a c2-2.5% FCF yield. As such, the acquirers would need to believe it could significantly increase Morrison's profitability (into national living wage and rates headwinds) to make sense of valuation and form a credible exit plan.

Property could in time give scope to refinance the business and but again significantly higher profitability would be needed to absorb rentals on property. Asset-stripping has been used many times to fund deals in the past, but we'd question the property market's appetite for so much single user, single use property coming its way.

undefined
BE

(@Pharma: .............. why?)

11:26 am
BE

ROTR want to talk about banks, even though it's a 2016 story rather than a Thursday story.

BE

Borked by negative rates, NIM squeezed, IB weak, capital looking progressively unpretty, counterparty risk pinned to oil ..... there are lots of reasons not to own banks, but none is fresh today.

BE

I guess we could preview HSBC figures, though. Due February 22.

11:29 am
BE

4am release, because Hong Kong, so not a good day for analysts.

BE

Here's what Deutsche expects.

BE

We forecast stated PBT for the quarter of US$1,887m and adjusted PBT of
US$3.1bn with US$80m of UK customer redress and US$1,1bn of restructuring
& related costs. Key issues for HSBC remain the outlook for revenues amidst a
more difficult market environment, cost reductions (we remain cautious given
past performance and potential revenue offset), and capital progression (we
forecast 11.9% at FY15). We have rebuilt our HSBC model, which has triggered
material negative changes to forecasts. Our Target Price falls to 500p from
580p previously, and our recommendation remains Hold.

11:30 am
BE

We have rebuilt our HSBC model (please contact us if you would like a copy);
we lower our forecasts materially. This leaves HSBC trading at 9.1x 2016
adjusted EPS, 0.8x 2016 TNAV for an underlying RoTE of ~9% RoTE for 2016e-
2018e, and a div. yield of 7-8% (cash yield of 5-6%), similar to the sector val. of
8.8x 2016 EPS, 7-8% div. yield, 0.8x TNAV. Our TP falls to 500p (derived via a
SoTP and DDM model)--above the current share price, but given a similar val.
vs the wider sector, we retain our Hold. Key upside risks: improvement in
Emerging Markets outlook, lower-than-expected loan losses, better-thanexpected
outcomes for regulation, lower costs. Key downside risks: regulatory
change, legacy liabilities, and a slowdown in emerging markets.

HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 457.27, up 0.3181 (+0.07%), High: 459.25, Low: 451.45, Volume: 5.30m
BE

As for the sector ..

11:32 am
Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 438.50, down 7.75 (-1.74%), High: 451.20, Low: 435.65, Volume: 2.97m
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 167.31, down 0.8351 (-0.50%), High: 169.50, Low: 163.65, Volume: 14.84m
Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 260.00, up 2.7 (+1.05%), High: 260.70, Low: 254.50, Volume: 4.56m
11:32 am
Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 63.48, up 0.69 (+1.10%), High: 63.49, Low: 62.12, Volume: 34.24m
BE

And not a scrap of news on any of them.

BE

So. That was a useful diversion.

11:33 am
BE

Back to retail.

undefined
BE

Today's fantasy M&A comes via Jefferies

11:34 am
BE

Which argues in favour of an Ashley take-private of Sports Direct

BE

The same Ashley take-private of Sports Direct that "friends of Ashley" told the Times a month ago absolutely wasn't happening.

BE

Whatever, though. Let's hear them out.

11:36 am
BE

Recent events highlight a widening gulf between Mike Ashley's long-term vision and growing governance concerns in the City. We believe the shares currently price in an over-pessimistic outlook, and Mr Ashley should consider taking SPD private given the group's free cashflow generation and underleveraged B/S. PT cut to 550p but we stay on Buy.

A torrid start to 2016 has come with a warning from SPD in response to weak sales in the closing stages of 2015. We have cut estimates by 7% for this year to reflect that. We downgrade longer term estimates by 14%/18% as we recognise UK retail operations have reached a margin peak. Still, a 9x cal 2017 P/E confirms just how under water sentiment is.

Our price checks provide some encouragement at a time when investors are understandably debating whether the combination of slowing sales and gross margin expansion indicates mgmt. has been protecting profits at the detriment of the customer offering. In the UK we have found SPD to have maintained a strong lead on pricing in third party brands relative to other scale retailers. And while the discount positioning of owned brands vs. external ones has eroded a little in the past two years, it continues to represent a compelling trading down option in SPD stores.

BE

A few factors should underpin a return to MSD growth from 16/17E as we speculate on the potential for international margins to have troughed in 15/16E, and the extent to which a foray into the discount gym segment can provide an alternative source of profits in the UK in coming years. At this juncture we assume only limited success in SPD's efforts to better position itself at the fashion end of the market despite recognising the capex requirements of shifting the store portfolio to a mix more conducive to a wider customer audience.

And finally Mr. Ashley's take private option looks compelling here as the £1.48bn of required capital needed for a 550p take out compares with SPD's adjusted net debt/EBITDAR of 1.3x and expected cumulative freecashflow of greater than £700m in the next three years. The business could repay c.40% of that capital requirement with two years of freecashflow and the cash raised from selling its JD Sports stake (before even considering utilising SPD's own B/S to raise more funds).

BE

Okay.

11:04 am
BE

Or at least we might, if the system starts working.

BE

First, would shareholders -- who implicitly back Ashley by owning the shares in spite of Sports Direct's horrific record on corporate governance -- take 550p?

Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 414.90, down 4.7 (-1.12%), High: 423.80, Low: 407.10, Volume: 992.66k
11:38 am
BE

Second, how would Sports Direct function as a private company?

BE

The main purpose of its listing is to give staff bonuses.

BE

I guess they could keep doing so in some kind of private, Ashley Dollars way.

11:41 am
BE

But the argument that Ashley would rather not face the glare of City scrutiny would seem to ignore the fact that he's spent half a decade showing very little sign of giving a monkeys about what anyone else thinks.

BE

Still. Nice idea. So we note it.

undefined
11:43 am
BE

(@Via Con: I think the first part of the statement is correct and the second probably isn't.)

BE

Quick bit of DPL, perhaps?

BE

Squeeze on Berkeley this morning.

11:44 am
Berkeley Group Holdings PLC (BKG:LSE): Last: 3,403, up 107.3 (+3.26%), High: 3,407, Low: 3,318, Volume: 255.40k
BE

Whole sector up, but Berkeley showing the strongest bounce.

BE

Goldman Sachs broadly positive on the sector, in a note I think went to clients yesterday.

11:45 am
BE

Following recent investor conversations and a roadshow with Crest
Nicholson’s management, we believe most investors are familiar with the
attractive factors (including resilient demand, policy support, attractive
land) driving the UK housebuilding cycle higher, but remain concerned
about the sustainability of these conditions over the medium-term as the
sector is currently generating near-historic peak margins and returns.

BE

We highlight 5 key factors that could cause our positive view on the
housebuilding fundamentals to change:
1) An unfavourable shift in the land market, impacting returns.
2) A slowing macro backdrop, dampening housing demand.
3) A less supportive lending environment, limiting activity levels.
4) Stretched affordability (particularly London), constraining market
growth.
5) A spike in build costs, impacting margin expansion forecasts.
Our assessment of the trends being seen across these areas suggest that
the medium-term outlook for the housebuilders remains broadly positive –
although uncertainty from upcoming headwinds such as the higher stamp
duty charges, and a potential EU referendum may impact activity levels
near term.

BE

UK housebuilder shares have been fairly resilient ytd (-11%) in the context
of our broader Construction coverage (-13%) although weak relative to the
FTSE 100 (-4%); our valuations now imply c.30% potential upside. We
continue to see most attractive upside in the mid-sized housebuilders,
which offer 14% CY16-19E EPS CAGRs and trade at a discount to larger
peers. Our top pick remains Crest Nicholson (CL-Buy) which offers
attractive growth and yield it looks to grow towards optimal scale

11:47 am
BE

But back to Berkeley .......

BE

You'll remember various funds going short since the start of the year.

BE

One of their key arguments seems to be related to Berkeley's revenue recognition.

11:48 am
BE

And while it's not my job to do the work of the short sellers, it's quite an interesting theme.

BE

So as I understand it, back in 2005 Berkeley switched to IAS 18 for its housing schemes.

BE

Here's the revenue restatement explainer from that year

11:50 am
BE

On traditional developments under UK GAAP, properties were treated as sold and profits were taken when contracts were exchanged and the building work was physically complete. On complex multi-unit developments, revenue and profit were recognised on a staged basis, commencing when the building work was substantially complete, which was defined as being plastered, and when contracts were exchanged.
On transition to IFRS, the Group has amended its policy to recognise revenue on properties on both traditional and complex multi-unit developments when contracts are exchanged and the building work is physically complete. This brings the policy on complex multi-unit developments into line with the Group’s existing revenue recognition policy on traditional developments and reflects the provisions of IAS 18 (“Revenue”).

BE

To me, IAS 18 looks a bit muddy on when to recognise revenue.

BE

(With the disclaimer that I'm not an accountant, so everything tends to look a bit muddy.)

11:51 am
BE

You need to go to a guidance note, IFRIC 15 Agreements for the Construction of Real
Estate ...

BE

Which puts a lot of emphasis on the point at which the buyer loses the option to make changes to the design

BE

And as I understand it, a person putting down a deposit also cedes the option to make changes.

11:52 am
BE

So there's no requirement to use IAS 18's percentage-of-completion method to recognise revenue.

BE

Now, I'm kinda needing two simple answers from all this.

BE

How much revenue is Berkeley booking upfront based on deposits?

11:53 am
BE

And how many of those deposits are being paid in emerging market currencies that have crapped out against sterling over the past few months?

BE

To reiterate, I'm no expert here. But the short case against Berkeley does look to be one wirth further investigation.

undefined
11:55 am
BE

Odd session, this. I'm not sure there's been a single moment when the right and left-hand sides have been on the same subject.

BE

Which is fine. Tech problems are a hurdle for the left-hand side so it's nice that you can find your own entertainment.

BE

Indivior requested .....

11:57 am
Indivior PLC (INDV:LSE): Last: 166.30, up 18.6 (+12.59%), High: 166.50, Low: 142.70, Volume: 1.39m
BE

Results beat.

BE

Basically, Indivior remains the market equivalent of that joke about the guy whose parachute doesn't open.....

11:59 am
BE

And as he plummets, he says: "still okay ....... still okay ........... still okay ........"

BE

So the message in today's results is that it's still okay.

BE

Jefferies can summarise.

12:00 pm
BE

ndivior's 2015 results were positive with revenues in line and a net income beat vs. JEFe and consensus. 2016 guidance looks upbeat, with the mid-point for revenue in line with JEFe and slightly above consensus. We note that a ruling for the ongoing litigation is expected in early Q2.

BE

2015 financials beat: Revenues were in line with consensus and our expectations, Suboxone film’s market share was 59% vs. 62% for 2014, although higher than 2014’s exit share. EBIT beat; we note that these figures exclude the $31m of exceptional costs, $15m from within SG&A and relating to the establishment of Indivior as a stand-alone company and $16m due to the discontinuation of Nasal Naloxone following the non-approval. Net debt $174m vs. JEFe $210m improves strategic flexibility ($428m end 2014).

Net Revenues: $1,014m vs. JEFe $1,012m & Cons. $1,008m.
Adjusted Operating Profit: $377m vs. JEFe $365m & Cons. $378m.
Adjusted Net Income: $246m vs. JEFe $224m & Cons. $224m.
Adjusted EPS: $0.34 vs. JEFe $0.31 & Cons. $0.32.

BE

No future dividend: Indivior announced a FY dividend of 12.7c (JEFe 12.5c) but that it does not expect to pay a dividend for the foreseeable future. We had viewed this as a possibility given a traditional specialty pharma business model; hence had assumed a halving of the 40% 2015 payout ratio to 20% in our model prior to any policy being announced.

2016 guidance reconfirmed: The company commented that Suboxone lost a number of managed Medicaid, and one fee for service, accounts to heavily discounted prices from branded competitors; Indivior believes this more than outweighs the recovery of formulary access at CVS from January 2016 and expects some modest share erosion over the next six months. With regard to costs, the company will be increasing pre-commercialisation projects in advance of the monthly depot launch.

Sales: $945-975m (JEFe $960m and Cons. $927m).
Operating margin greater than 30% (JEFe 30.0% and Cons. 30.0%).
Net Income: $155-180m (JEFe $173m and Cons. $164m).

Litigation ongoing, ruling likely in Q2: Indivior expects a ruling in early Q2 for the Actavis and Par cases. There are now six ANDA filers seeking approval for generic Suboxone Film.

Pipeline on track but no significant updates: Given the detail provided at the recent R&D day in December, we did not expect any substantial updates. See our recent report for a more detailed overview – “Indivior R&D Day”.

Other upcoming events: The PDUFA date for Titan/Braeburn’s probuphine is currently set for 27 February 2016, and although the FDA is not bound to follow the positive PDAC recommendation, we believe it likely. Our view is that the impact will be relatively slight, if approval is achieved.

12:01 pm
undefined
BE

There's also Tullow, of course.

BE

Their ship's lost the ability to go squint.

12:02 pm
Tullow Oil PLC (TLW:LSE): Last: 178.70, down 12.7 (-6.64%), High: 188.70, Low: 173.10, Volume: 7.47m
BE

So, rather than have stuff reported in the local press get picked up by the likes of us and send the shares down 30%, they've put out a holding statement.

BE

Which is best practice, and laudable, but also rather underlines how much the Tullow investment case is reliant on everything going perfectly.

12:04 pm
BE

As we've said before, the problem with Tullow is that if one roughneck drops a spanner down a pipe you're on the hook for a rights issue.

BE

Barclays incoming.

BE

Our view: Tullow has disclosed a potential issue with the Jubilee FPSO turret bearing, a move we believe should avoid incomplete reporting of the operational changes in the Ghanaian media. The key message is that production continues as normal, but the existence of the issue does raise a new known unknown within the Tullow investment case. The Jubilee field accounts for 44% of our 278p/share Tangible NAV. We continue to rate the stock Overweight with a 280p price target.

12:05 pm
BE

Issue: A recent inspection of the Jubilee FPSO turret identified a potential issue with the turret bearing. As a precautionary measure, monitoring of the turret bearings has increased while the degree of vessel rotation is being reduced using tug boats. SOFEC, the turret manufacturer is undertaking further offshore examinations and will work with Tullow to determine any further measures required. SOFEC is also the manufacturer of the external turret installed on the FPSO to be used for Tullow's TEN development.

Impact: Production from Jubilee is not affected, with the field accounting for 45% of our 2016E net production forecast for the company. We believe the precautionary measures should only marginally impact operating costs. Tullow has FPSO insurance and production interruption insurance, limiting the potential for any future remedial activity to materially impact Tullow's financial position.

BE

Yes, but what is a turret?

BE

What's a turret? An external turret (like the one on the Jubilee FPSO) is attached to the end of the vessel and moored (anchored) to the seabed. It has bearings that enable the vessel to rotate 360 degrees around the static turret. This allows the FPSO to be ideally positioned in response to weather conditions and water currents.

12:06 pm
BE

There you go.

undefined
BE

Oh, look at the time.

12:08 pm
BE

(@nichoman: that struck me as curious too, but didn't have time to investigate.)

BE

Last day of half term tomorrow, and also the last day of Murphy's journey into the Heart of Darkness ....

BE

Though he has a habit of missing his flight, so I make no guarantees for Monday.

12:10 pm
BE

Let's worry about that after Friday though, which we'll worry about after this afternoon.

BE

Thanks, ROTR.

BE

There are a couple of issues here.
